page.title: 19AUTOBIOGRAPHY
page.content: Frederick Bennett,Born November 1919,the youngest of a family of 9. I think my earliest memories are of the 1926 General Strike,of meetings and unrest but little of the actual details.Schooling was Newbiggin Infants School,Newbiggin Colliery School and then the'Modern School' leaving at the age of 14. I had hoped to pass an examination for the Secondary School but for financial reasons this was impossible. I left school at Christmas and started work in a shop in Ashington tending heating boilers and making deliveries by a handcart. The normal working week was 64 hours for a wage of 12/6d(about 60p). After a year I changed to another shop as an assistant.At the start of World War II, I was called up for the Army and was soon promoted to serjeant.In London during the Blitz
